ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Claims against city officers and departments. 
(a)  If a claim or lawsuit is filed against any employee or official of the city that relates to the performance of his duty with the city, such claim or lawsuit shall be defended or settled if such claim or lawsuit is not covered by liability insurance or unless the mayor and council shall direct otherwise. 
(b)  A claim or lawsuit against a city official or employee shall not be defended or settled if the employee has been grossly negligent or engaged in willful or wanton misconduct in the performance of his duties. If liability insurance covers a portion of the defense of such employee but not all of the defense, then the city attorney shall defend that portion not covered by insurance, subject to the approval of the mayor and council. 
(c)  If a claim or lawsuit against a city official or employee results in damages or costs being assessed against such employee or official, the city shall have the right, but not the obligation, to reimburse or indemnify such employee or official from such loss. 
(d)  The city shall have the right, but not the obligation, to provide for reimbursement to a city officer or employee for reasonable legal fees and other expenses in the successful defense of a criminal action arising out of the performance of official duties. 
(Code 1986, § 2-4-2) 
Sec. 2-2. - Administration and service departments. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the mayor and city council by ordinance shall prescribe the functions or duties and establish, abolish, or alter all nonelective offices, positions of employment, departments, and agencies of the city as necessary for the proper administration of the affairs and government of this city. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by this chapter or by law, the directors of departments, agencies, and other appointed officers of the city shall be appointed solely on the basis of their respective administrative and professional qualifications. 
(c)  All appointed officials shall receive such compensation as approved by the mayor and council. Department and agency heads shall receive compensation approved by the city manager. 
(d)  There shall be a director of each department and agency who shall be its principal officer. Each director shall, subject to the direction and supervision of the city manager, be responsible for the administration and direction of the affairs and operations of his/her department or agency. 
(e)  All directors shall be selected by the city manager with confirmation by the mayor and council. The city manager may suspend or remove directors under his/her supervision, but such suspension or removal shall not be effective for three calendar days following the city manager's giving written notice of such action and the reasons therefore to the director involved and to the mayor and council. The director involved may appeal to the municipal court judge, which, after a hearing, may override the city manager's action. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2004-55, § 1, 11-15-04; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 2-3. - Records. 
(a)  Record retention. The city adopts the record management plan and record retention schedules recommended by the Georgia Secretary of State pursuant to Georgia Records Act, Article 5, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-90, as amended from time to time, by resolution by the mayor and council of the city of Kennesaw. A copy of such management plan and record retention schedule is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
The city clerk shall be the records officer and assistant city clerk as authorized deputy records officer (O.C.G.A. 50-18-71(b)(1)(B)) and shall coordinate all records management for the city including storage, archiving and destruction of records, excluding the police department and municipal court. 
The support services commander has been designated as the records manager for the police department as approved in the police department standard operating procedures manual. The municipal court clerk shall be designated as the records manager for the municipal court. 
Records shall be maintained according to the approved retention schedule, and no record shall be destroyed except as provided in the approved retention schedule. Any changes to the retention schedules shall be adopted by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(b)  Open record request. All requests made under the Georgia Open Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70, as may be amended from time to time, shall be made to the records officer. 
(c)  Minutes. The official record of the City of Kennesaw meetings shall consist of the written meeting minutes voted and accepted by the council at their next regularly scheduled meeting. The official record of every committee, agency, board, commission and authority shall consist of the written meeting minutes voted and accepted at the next regularly scheduled meeting of said committee, agency, board, commission and authority. 
(Ord. No. 2003-11, § 1, 4-4-03; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2008-36, § 1, 10-6-08; Ord. No. 2012-05, 7-2-12) 
Secs. 2-4—2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Personal liability of council members and other municipal officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-4; code of ethics for government service, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1. 

Sec. 2-26. - Regular meeting place and time. 
The mayor and council shall meet at the city hall in regular session on the first and third Mondays of each month at 6:30 p.m., except on the holidays enumerated in the city's employee personnel manual, which dates shall be set in advance by the mayor and council. In addition thereto, the mayor and council may set such additional regular meeting dates by providing at least seven days' notice of their intention and upon majority vote of the council. 
(Code 1986, § 2-1-1; Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1, 3-4-02; Ord. No. 2006-23, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
State Law reference— Meetings to be open to public, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1; exemptions from open meeting requirements, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3; due notice requirements for other than regular meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d); requirement to prescribe the time, place and dates of regular meetings of governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). 
Sec. 2-27. - Parliamentary rules. 
When any question arises which is not provided for in the rules of the council, the question, as far as practicable, shall be controlled by Roberts Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Code 1986, § 2-1-2; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07)

ARTICLE III. - CITY MANAGER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1996-7, adopted 9-3-96, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 2-51—2-59 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 6-6-4, §§ 2-5-1—2-5-9. 
State Law reference— Power to define, regulate and alter the powers, duties, qualifications, compensation and tenure of municipal officers, agents and employees, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(2). 

Sec. 2-51. - Appointment; qualifications; compensation. 
The mayor and city council shall appoint a city manager for an indefinite term and shall fix his/her compensation. The city manager shall be appointed solely on the basis of his/her executive and administrative qualifications and shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 2-52. - Removal. 
(a)  The mayor and council may remove the city manager from office upon a majority vote of the mayor and council. 
(1)  After a majority vote to remove the city manager, the city manager shall have the right to request a public or private hearing within two weeks of the request. Such request shall be made within 48 hours after dismissal. After said hearing, the mayor and council may adopt a final resolution for removal, which may be made effective immediately, by an affirmative vote of a majority of the membership of the council and office of mayor or reinstate said city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 2-53. - Acting city manager. 
The mayor and council may designate, an acting city manager to exercise the powers and perform the duties of city manager during his/her temporary absence or disability. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 2-54. - Powers and duties. 
The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the city. S/he shall be responsible to the mayor and council for the administration of all city affairs placed in his/her charge by or under this or other ordinance or resolution. S/he shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  The city manager, with the express approval of the mayor and council, shall appoint department heads other than city clerk, and city auditor, judge and solicitor of the municipal court and city attorney which shall be appointed by the mayor and council; 
(2)  S/he shall appoint and, when s/he deems it necessary for the good of the city, suspend or remove all other city employees, except as otherwise provided by law or personnel ordinances adopted pursuant to this chapter. S/he may authorize any department head who is subject to his/her direction and supervision to exercise these powers with respect to subordinates in that officer's department, office, or agency; 
(3)  S/he shall direct and supervise the administration of all departments, offices, and agencies of the city, except as otherwise provided by the City Charter or by law; 
(4)  S/he shall attend all council meetings and shall have the right to take part in discussion but s/he may not vote; 
(5)  S/he shall see that all laws, provisions of the City Charter, and acts of the mayor and council subject to enforcement by him/her or by officers subject of his/her directions and supervision, are faithfully executed; 
(6)  S/he shall prepare and submit the annual operating budget and capital budget to the mayor and council; s/he shall prepare and submit monthly financial reports and list of bills for each department to the mayor and council. 
(7)  S/he shall submit to the mayor and council and make available to the public a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the city as of the end of each fiscal year; 
(8)  S/he shall make such other reports as the mayor and council may require concerning the operations of the city departments, offices, and agencies subject to his/her direction and supervision; 
(9)  S/he shall keep the mayor and council fully advised as to the financial condition and future needs of the city and make such recommendations to the mayor and council concerning the affairs of the city as s/he deems desirable; and 
(10)  S/he shall perform such other duties as are specified in this article or as may be required by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 2-55. - Council interference with administration. 
Except for the purpose of inquiries and investigations, the mayor and members of the city council shall deal with city officers and employees who are subject to the direction and supervision of the city manager solely through the city manager, and neither the mayor nor members of the city council shall give orders to any such officer or employee, either publicly or privately. In the case of a city emergency involving public health or safety and in the absence of the city manager, the mayor or a member of council may direct activities as appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 2-56. - Bond. 
The city manager shall be bonded, with the bond premium paid by the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his/her duties and secure against corruption, malfeasance, misappropriation, or unlawful expenditures, by a bonding company licensed to do business in the State of Georgia, and approved by the mayor and council, in an amount not less than $50,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Secs. 2-57—2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, AUTHORITIES AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-71. - Boards, commissions, and authorities. 
(a)  The mayor and city council shall create by ordinance such boards, commissions, and authorities to fulfill any investigative, quasi-judicial, or quasi-legislative function the mayor and city council deem necessary and shall by ordinance establish the composition, period of existence, duties, and powers thereof. 
(b)  All members of boards, commissions, and authorities of the city shall be appointed by the mayor and city council for such terms of office and in such manner as shall be provided by ordinance, except where other appointing authority, terms of office, or manner of appointment is prescribed by this ordinance or by law. 
(c)  The mayor and city council, by ordinance, may provide for the compensation and reimbursement for actual and necessary expenses of the members of any board, commission, or authority. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided by charter, ordinance, or by other law, no member of any board, commission, or authority shall hold any elective office in the city. 
(e)  Any vacancy on a board, commission, or authority of the city shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner prescribed for the original appointment, except as otherwise provided by this chapter or by law. 
(f)  No member of a board, commission, or authority shall assume office until s/he has executed and filed with the clerk of the city an oath obligating such member to perform faithfully and impartially the duties of his/her office, such oath to be prescribed by ordinance and administered by the mayor. 
(g)  Except as otherwise provided by state law, any member of a board, commission, or authority may be removed from office for cause by a majority vote of the mayor and city council. Cause shall be defined as malfeasance or misfeasance in office or failure to attend three consecutive regular, scheduled meetings or failure to attend a minimum of 70 percent of such regularly scheduled board, commission, or authority meetings within any calendar year. While attendance in person is preferred, a member of a board, commission, or authority may attend a meeting by telephonic means. All votes in which a member is present via telephonic means shall require a roll call vote which shall be recorded in the minutes. 
(h)  Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or by law, each board, commission, or authority of the city shall elect one of its members as chairman and one member as vice-chairman, and may elect as its secretary one of its own members or may appoint as secretary an employee of the city. Each board, commission, or authority of the city government may establish such bylaws, rules, and regulations, not inconsistent with this chapter, ordinances of the city, or law, as it deems appropriate and necessary for the fulfillment of its duties or the conduct of its affairs. Copies of such bylaws, rules, and regulations shall be filed with the clerk of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1996-7, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07) 
Secs. 2-72—2-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Downtown development authority created, O.C.G.A. § 36-42-4. 

Sec. 2-76. - Declaration of need. 
It is determined and declared that there is a present, continuing and future need for a downtown development authority, as more fully described and defined in the Downtown Development Authorities Law as set forth, to function within the city as referenced in O.C.G.A. § 36-42 dated 2012 as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1-1; Res. of 7-5-95(1); Ord. No. 2013-02, 2-4-13) 
Sec. 2-77. - Activation. 
There is reactivated in the city a public body corporate and politic known as the Kennesaw Downtown Development Authority, which is hereby reconstituted upon the adoption and approval of this section. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1-2; Res. of 7-5-95(1)) 
Sec. 2-78. - Membership of board of directors. 
The mayor and city council hereby establish an initial board of directors consisting of seven members, each of whom meets the qualifications of O.C.G.A. § 36-42-7. The terms of the initial board of directors shall be staggered. Upon the expiration of the initial terms of these members, directors shall serve for six-year terms or as prescribed by the laws of the state, whichever is more restrictive. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1-3; Res. of 7-5-95(1)) 
Sec. 2-79. - Organization. 
The board of directors named in this division shall be authorized to organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq., and as it may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1-4; Res. of 7-5-95(1)) 
Sec. 2-80. - Boundary description of downtown development area. 
The geographical area of the downtown development area shall be as shown on a plat prepared by the city engineer, an official copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. The downtown development area has such size, shape, location, dimensions, metes, bounds, courses and distances as are shown on such plat, reference to which is made for all purposes of description. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1-5; Res. of 7-5-95(1)) 
Sec. 2-81. - Effect. 
The action taken by the mayor and city council as specified in this article is not intended in any way to affect any public corporation, industrial development, downtown development or payroll authority previously created by legislative act or constitutional amendment, including, without limitation, its existence, purpose, organization and powers of function. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1-6; Res. of 7-5-95(1)) 
Secs. 2-82—2-85. - Reserved.

The mayor and city council hereby declare that there is a need for a development authority to function in the city to carry forth the purposes set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. 
(Res. of 7-5-95(2))

The mayor and city council do hereby create the Kennesaw Development Authority pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. 
(Res. of 7-5-95(2))

The terms of the initial board of directors shall be staggered. Thereafter, their successors shall be appointed in accordance with the provisions of the development authorities act. 
(Res. of 7-5-95(2))

DIVISION 4. - BOARD OF ETHICS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for government service, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1; code of ethics for members of boards, commissions and authorities, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-3. 

Sec. 2-91. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Advisory opinion means the board of ethics interpretation to a written request as to whether a particular course of conduct would constitute a violation of the applicable ethical standards outlined hereto. 
Board of ethics means the entity created by section 2-98. 
Business means a corporation, a partnership, a sole proprietor, or any other person or organization carrying on an enterprise whether for profit or not. 
City means the City of Kennesaw, Georgia. 
Complaint means a written sworn statement filed with the city containing specific allegations of misconduct by a member of the governing authority; provided, however, such allegations must be filed within six months after the complaining party knew or should have reasonably known of the alleged misconduct. 
Confidential information means any information that by law or practice is not available to the public. 
Conflict of interest means an individual has multiple interests and uses his or her official position to exploit, in some way, his or her position for his or her own direct, unique, pecuniary, and personal benefit. 
Consultant means any person not a member of the governing authority, who is not an employee of the city, who is retained to render personal services of a technical or professional nature, whether paid or unpaid, and who has other personal or private employment. The term "consultant" includes, but is not limited to, attorneys, architects, engineers, surveyors, accountants, brokers, financial advisers and title abstractors. 
Contract means any claim or demand against or any lease, account or agreement with any person, whether express or implied, executed or executory, verbal or in writing. 
Emergency situation means any circumstance or condition giving rise to an immediate necessity for the execution of a contract by and between the city and a member of the governing authority or between the city and a business in which a member of the governing authority has an interest and where as defined in the city code section 34-2(a): 
(1)  It is shown that there is no person located within a reasonable geographic distance who could have provided the goods and services needed to meet the emergency other than the member or the business in which the member has an interest; and 
(2)  The necessity was not brought about by the fault or neglect of the person contracting with the city. 
Gift means any benefit or thing of value which is conveyed to or performed for the benefit of a public servant or a partner in interest, including any advance, award, contract, contribution, deposit, employment, favor, forbearance, gift, gratuity, honorarium, loan, payment, service, subscription, or the promise that any of these things or acts of value will be conferred in the future, if such thing or act of value is conferred or performed without the lawful exchange of consideration which is at least equal in value to the thing or act conferred or performed. 
Governing authority or member of the governing authority unless otherwise expressly defined does not include city employees but does mean the mayor, members of city council, municipal court judge or municipal court judge pro tem, city manager, and city clerk. The term also includes all individuals, including city employees, appointed by the mayor and/or council as appropriate to city authorities, commissions, committees, boards, task forces or other bodies which can or may vote and take formal action or make official recommendations to the mayor and/or council. The term "member" may be used throughout this division to refer to an individual member of the governing authority. 
Immediate family means a member's spouse, domestic partner, parent, sibling, child and grandparent. Also includes any of these persons of a step, in-law and foster or adoptive relationship to the member of the governing authority. 
Interest means any direct or indirect financial or personal benefit, which is not a remote interest, held by or accruing to a member of the governing authority as a result of a contract or transaction that is or may be the subject of an official act or action by or with the city. A member of the governing authority shall be deemed to have an interest in transactions involving: 
(1)  Any person in the member's immediate family; 
(2)  Any person with whom a contractual relationship exists whereby the member may receive any payment or other benefit unless the member is receiving a benefit for goods or services in the normal course of business for which the member has paid a commercially reasonable rate; 
(3)  Any business in which the member is a director, officer, employee or shareholder, except as otherwise provided herein; or 
(4)  Any person of whom the member is a creditor, whether secured or unsecured. 
Official act or action means any tangible act or inaction relating to a legislative, administrative, appointive or discretionary act of a member of the governing authority. 
Paid means the receipt of, or right to receive, a salary, a commission, a dividend or percentage, brokerage or contingent fee. 
Participate means to take part in official acts, actions or proceedings personally as a member of the governing authority through approval, disapproval, decision, recommendation, investigation, the rendering of advice or the failure to perform a duty or the failure to act; provided, however, abstention required by this document is not participation. 
Person means any individual, business, labor organization, representative, fiduciary, trust or association, whether paid or unpaid, and includes any member of the governing authority. 
Property means any property, whether real or personal, or tangible or intangible, and includes currency and commercial paper. 
Remote interest means the interest of: 
(1)  A nonsalable director, officer, or employee of a nonprofit corporation exempt from federal income tax pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States; 
(2)  A holder of less than five percent of the legal or beneficial ownership of the total share of a business; or 
(3)  Action of a member in which the member receives a benefit common to residents of the municipality, generally including but not limited to the adoption of the general budget and adoption or substantial revision of the land use plan or zoning ordinance of the city. 
Transaction means the conduct of any activity that results in or may result in an official act or action of the governing authority of the city. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 2; Ord. No. 2000-09, 3-6-00; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-92. - Intent. 
It is essential to the proper administration and operation of the city that the members of its governing authority be, and give the appearance of being, independent and impartial; that public office not be used for private gain; and that there be public confidence in the integrity of the governing authority. The governing authority finds that the public interest requires that they protect against such conflicts of interest by establishing appropriate ethical standards with respect to the conduct of the members of the governing authority in situations where a conflict may exist. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 1; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-93. - Prohibitions; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be deemed a conflict of interest if a member of the governing authority: 
(1)  By conduct, give reasonable basis for the impression that any person can improperly influence or unduly enjoy favor in the performance of official acts or actions or that such member is affected unduly by the rank or position of or association with any person. 
(2)  Gifts, loans, favors. Directly or indirectly request, exact, receive or agree to receive a gift, loan, favor, promise or thing of value for himself or another person if: 
a.  It could reasonably be considered to influence the member in the discharge of official duties; or 
b.  The member recently has been, is now, or within one year in the future, is involved in any official act or action that results in a pecuniary benefit for the donor or lender that is not available to the public at large. 
(b)  Subsection (a)(2) of this section shall not apply in the case of: 
(1)  An occasional nonpecuniary gift of insignificant value, for example, items received while at a convention, receipt of trinkets or gifts (such as a calendar, memento or pen) received in the normal course of business with a value of less than $100.00 (or $75.00 if received from a lobbyist as defined in O.C.G.A. § 21-5-70) and admission to and/or consumption of food at a breakfast, lunch, dinner, function or event. 
(2)  An award publicly presented in recognition of public service. 
(3)  A transaction authorized by and performed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6, as now or hereafter amended. 
(4)  A commercially reasonable loan or other financial transaction made in the ordinary course of business by an institution or individual authorized by the laws of the state to engage in the making of such a loan or financial transaction. 
(5)  Campaign contributions made and reported in accordance with state law. 
(c)  Disclose or otherwise use confidential information acquired by virtue of his/her position for his/her, or another person's or business's private gain. 
(d)  Use his/her official position or office to attempt to secure privileges that are not available to the general public. 
(e)  Engage in, accept employment with or render services for any private business or professional activity when such employment or rendering of services is adverse to and incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties. For the purposes of this subsection, the employment of a consultant by any business involving matters unrelated to any contract or transaction by or with the city shall not be deemed incompatible with such consultant's official duties. 
(f)  Engage in any activity or transaction that is prohibited by law now existing or hereafter enacted which is applicable to him by virtue of being a member of the governing authority. 
(g)  Attempt to acquire, use or procure public resources not available to the general public for private gain or personal purposes. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 3; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-94. - Disclosure of conflicts of interest. 
(a)  A member of the governing authority who has an interest shall disclose the precise nature and value of such interest by sworn written statement to the city clerk and to the chairperson of the board of ethics prior to the governing authority taking official action on a matter affecting such interest. Such sworn statements shall be a public record. 
(b)  A member of the governing authority who has an ongoing relationship with a business or individual arising out of the normal course of commerce for which such member receives compensation at a commercially reasonable rate shall disclose such relationship if the city has or can be reasonably anticipated to purchase goods or services from such business or individual. A disclosure of such relationship shall be made annually and when becoming aware of a possible conflict of interest. Such disclosures will be made in writing describing the nature of the relationship, the member and other parties in the relationship and the interest of the member in such relationship. Such disclosures shall be kept on file by the city clerk and a copy sent to the chairperson of the board of ethics. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 4; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-95. - Disqualification. 
A member of the governing authority shall disqualify him/herself from participating in any official act or action of the city that results in a benefit to the member or a business or activity in which s/he has an interest, when such benefit is not available to the public at large. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 5; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-96. - Prohibited contracts. 
No member of the governing authority or business in which that member of the governing authority has more than a remote interest shall enter into any contract involving services or property with the city. This section shall not apply in the case of: 
(1)  The designation of a bank or trust company as a depository for city funds. 
(2)  The borrowing of funds from any bank or lending institution which offers the lowest available rate of interest in the community for such loan. 
(3)  Contracts entered into in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6. 
(4)  Contracts for services that are awarded pursuant to sealed competitive bids subsequent to an advertised competitive bid process in accordance with the purchasing ordinance of the city. 
(5)  Contracts entered into under circumstances which constitute an emergency situation in accordance with city Code section 34-2, Civil Emergencies, provided that a written record explaining the emergency is prepared by the mayor and thereafter kept on file with the city clerk. A copy of same shall be submitted by the city clerk to the board of ethics. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 6; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-97. - Restrictions on contracts with former members of the governmental authority. 
The city shall not enter into any contract with, or take any official act or action favorably affecting, any person, or business represented by such person when such person has been a member of the governing authority within the twelve (12) month period preceding such action, except when the governing authority had a contract with such person or business prior to the member leaving office or unless the business received the contract for having the lowest and best bid pursuant to the purchasing procedures established by the city. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 7; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-98. - Board of ethics—Created. 
(a)  There is created the board of ethics of the city, to be composed of five residents of the city, to be appointed as provided in subsection (b) of this section. Each member of the board of ethics shall have been a resident of the city for at least one year immediately preceding the date of taking office and shall remain a resident of the city while serving as a member of the board of ethics. No person shall serve as a member of the board of ethics if the person has, or has had within the immediately preceding two year period, any interest in any contract, transaction or official action of the city. No member of the board of ethics shall be a current member of the governing authority or employee of the city. 
(b)  The five members of the board of ethics shall be appointed by the mayor and city council. Appointees shall serve terms of two years from the appointment by mayor and council unless otherwise removed pursuant to this section or filling the remainder of a term for a member who has been removed. 
(c)  If a member of the board of ethics ceases to be a resident of the city during his term, that member's position on the board shall become vacant immediately. A vacancy in the board of ethics shall exist by reason of death, resignation or loss of residency as described in this subsection. A member of the board of ethics may also be removed from office during a term if the member becomes ineligible pursuant to one of the provisions listed in O.C.G.A. § 45-2-1, while applicable to civil office shall be also be applicable to the board of ethics, and that ineligibility is established by decision of a court of competent jurisdiction as required by said statute. A vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and city council. Further, members of the board of ethics may be removed by majority vote of mayor and council for cause, including, but not limited to, failure to maintain any requirement for qualification to serve on the board of ethics. 
(d)  The members of the board of ethics shall serve without compensation and shall elect from their own membership a chairperson and otherwise provide for their own internal organization. 
(e)  The governing authority of the city shall provide adequate office and meeting space for the board of ethics. Subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city: 
(1)  The city manager will provide the board of ethics with necessary staff support; and 
(2)  The city shall provide the board of ethics with such supplies and equipment as may be reasonably necessary for it to carry out its duties and responsibilities. The board of ethics shall be subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city; provided, however, in exercising its powers and duties pursuant to section 2-99, the board of ethics shall be independent and shall not be subject to control or supervision by any member of the governing body or employee of the city government. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 8; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-99. - Same—Duties and powers. 
The board of ethics shall have the following duties and powers subject to the establishment of a quorum which shall be three members of the board of ethics: 
(1)  To establish procedures, rules and regulations governing its internal organization and the conduct of its affairs. 
(2)  To render advisory opinions with respect to the interpretation and application of this section to any city resident, duly licensed business, and/or member of the governing authority who seeks, in writing, advice as to whether a particular course of conduct would constitute a violation of the standards imposed in this section or other applicable ethical standards. Such opinions shall be binding on the board of ethics in any subsequent complaint concerning the person who sought the opinion and acted in good faith, unless material facts were omitted or misstated in the request for the advisory opinion. 
(3)  To prescribe forms, approved by the city attorney, for the disclosures required in this division and to make available to the public the information disclosed as provided in this section. (The board shall be authorized to adopt forms for formal complaints, and any other written instruments necessary or desirable under the code of ordinances.) 
(4)  To receive and hear complaints of violations of the standards required by this division. 
(5)  To make such investigations in response to complaints as it deems necessary to determine whether any member of the governing authority has violated any provisions of this division. The board of ethics, as a result of a complaint filed with the board of ethics shall make such probable cause investigation as it deems proper to carry out its duties under this subsection. For the purpose of such investigation, the board of ethics may hold and conduct hearings, take evidence, examine witnesses and administer oaths and issue subpoenas when such subpoena power is authorized by law. All testimony taken by the board of ethics shall be under oath. The board of ethics shall apply to the superior court of the county for the enforcement of any subpoena issued by the board. 
(6)  At any hearing held under subsection (5) of this section, the member of the governing authority against whom the complaint was filed shall have the right to written notice of the allegations at least ten business days before a hearing, to be represented by counsel, to hear and examine the evidence and witnesses against the member of the governing authority and to preserve evidence and witnesses in opposition or in extenuation. 
(7)  To report its findings to the mayor and council. 
(8)  To select an attorney if the city attorney is not available or has a conflict of interest, at an hourly rate currently approved by mayor and council. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 9; Ord. No. 1998-11, 7-20-98; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-100. - Penalty. 
Any member of the governing authority who is found by the board of ethics to have knowingly violated any provision of the Code of Ethics shall be subject to such action as the mayor and council deem appropriate. Such action may include, but not be limited to, public reprimand or any other corrective and/or disciplinary action the mayor and council deem appropriate. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 10; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, adopted Dec. 15, 2014, amended the title of § 2-100, which was formerly titled "Penalty and appeals." Provisions relating to appeals now appear in § 2-101. 
Sec. 2-101. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any member of the governing authority or the complainant adversely affected by these findings of the board of ethics under section 2-100 may obtain judicial review of such decision as provided in this section. 
(b)  An action for judicial review may be commenced by filing an application for a writ of certiorari in the superior court of the county, within which the city is located, within 30 days after the decision of the board of ethics becomes final which is the date that the board votes on the complaint. 
(c)  Upon the filing of a writ of certiorari, any enforcement of the board's decision and/or mayor and council's penalty shall be postponed pending judicial review provided for in this section. 
(d)  The record on review, unless otherwise stipulated by the parties, shall include the original or certified copies of all pleadings, testimony, evidence, exhibits and other papers presented to or considered by the board of ethics and the findings and decision of the board of ethics. As to alleged procedural irregularities, evidence may be taken independently by the court. 
(e)  If the court finds no error, it shall affirm the decision of the board of ethics. If it finds that such decision of the board was: 
(1)  Arbitrary or capricious; 
(2)  A denial of a statutory right; 
(3)  Contrary to constitutional right, power, privilege or immunity; 
(4)  In excess of statutory jurisdiction, authority, purposes or limitation; 
(5)  Not in accord with the procedures or procedural limitations of this section or otherwise required by law; 
(6)  An abuse or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion, unsupported by substantial evidence when the record is considered as a whole; or 
(7)  Otherwise contrary to law; 
then the court shall hold such action by the board unlawful and set aside the decision of the board of ethics. 
(f)  The decision of the trial court shall be subject to appellate review in the same manner and with the same effect as in appeals from a final judgment or decree in any other civil action. 
(Ord. of 1-1-95, § 11; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-102. - Procedures for filing a complaint. 
(a)  In order to file a complaint, any city resident and/or duly licensed business owner in the city must do so in writing on the form prescribed by the board of ethics. Paper forms are available at the city clerk's office. The complaint should describe the facts that are alleged to constitute a violation, and be signed and sworn before the city clerk. If the complaint is against the city clerk, the complaint shall be delivered to the assistant clerk who shall be responsible for the actions normally conducted by the city clerk as set forth in this subsection. The city clerk will, no later than three working days after receipt, forward such complaint to the chairperson of the board of ethics or his/her designee. The city clerk will also immediately forward a copy of the complaint by registered mail to the member of the governing authority against whom the complaint was filed. The person filing the complaint shall verify at the time of filing that he/she or it is qualified, i.e. a city resident or duly licensed business owner in the city, to file a complaint. A complaint must be filed within six months of the date the alleged violation is said to have occurred, or in case of concealment or nondisclosure within six months of the date the alleged violation should have been discovered after due diligence. In the event the board of ethics makes an initial determination that a complaint is technically deficient, the board shall submit a list of deficiencies to the complainant and offer the complainant the opportunity to correct the deficiencies within 15 days from when the complainant receives notice of the deficiencies. In the event, six month limitation expires during the 15 day correction period, the complainant shall have the full 15 days to correct any deficiencies; however, in the event, the complaint is not resubmitted with all corrections on or before the fifteenth day, the complainant shall lose the right to file a complaint on that issue. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a complaint, alleging misconduct, the member of the governing authority against whom the complaint was filed may reply to the complaint in writing within 30 days from receipt of said complaint, unless such time for reply is shortened or extended by the board of ethics. Such response should be submitted to the city clerk who in turn shall immediately forward it to the chairperson of the board of ethics or his/her designee. 
(c)  Within 60 days of receipt by the city clerk of a complaint, the board of ethics shall conduct an investigatory review to determine whether specific substantiated evidence from a credible source(s) exists to support a reasonable belief that there has been a violation of this division. If after reviewing the complaint the board of ethics by majority vote determines that no specific, substantiated evidence from a credible source(s) exists to support reasonable belief that there has been a violation of this division or determines that no violation occurred, it may dismiss the complaint. In the event a complaint is dismissed on the basis of a deficiency in the form of the complaint, rather than upon the merits of the complaint, the complaint may be re-filed within 15 days from when the complainant receives notice of the deficiencies. 
(d)  If the board of ethics determines that specific, substantiated evidence from a credible source(s) exists to support a reasonable belief that there has been a violation of this division, certified written notice of a hearing, containing the time, date and place of such hearing, shall be given to each party by the board of ethics, and a formal public hearing shall be conducted and both parties afforded an opportunity to be heard. Any formal public hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements of due process. The board of ethics is authorized to swear witnesses. Any final determination resulting from the hearing shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law. The board shall determine if clear and convincing evidence shows any violation of this Code. Within seven days of the hearing, findings of the board of ethics shall be submitted to the mayor and city council for action. 
(e)  Nothing in this division shall be construed to limit or encumber the right of the board of ethics to initiate an investigation on its own cognizance, as it deems necessary to fulfill its obligations under this division. 
(f)  Any city resident and/or duly licensed business owner in the city may file a written request for an advisory opinion by completing an advisory opinion request form and filing it along with any supporting documents with the city clerk. The city clerk will forward the request to the chairperson of the board of ethics or his/her designee no later than three working days after receipt. In the event the chairperson of the board of ethics makes an initial determination that a complaint is technically deficient, the chairperson shall submit a list of deficiencies to the complainant and offer the complainant the opportunity to correct the deficiencies within 15 days from when the complainant receives notice of the deficiencies. The board will make a good faith effort to render any advisory opinion within 60 days from receipt. 
(Ord. No. 2000-09, 3-6-00; Ord. No. 2007-25, 8-6-07; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Sec. 2-103. - Reimbursements of legal expenses. 
City funds may be used to reimburse members of the governing authority for reasonable legal expenses incurred in their successful defense of the complaint if the board of ethics determines that the conduct complained of arises out of or was in connection with the performance of the member of the governing authorities official duties and that the member of the governing authority was engaged in the performance of his/her duties at the time the alleged misconduct occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2000-09, 3-6-00; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2014-19, Exh. A, 12-15-14) 
Secs. 2-104, 2-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PLANNING COMMISSION[6]

State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-106. - Members; officers; terms; quorums; meetings. 
(a)  The Kennesaw Planning Commission, referred to in this division as the planning commission, shall consist of seven members. 
(b)  A chairperson shall be elected by the planning commission at the first meeting of each year. A vice-chairperson shall be elected at the first meeting of each year and shall serve in the absence of the chairperson. 
(c)  Members of the planning commission shall be appointed by the mayor and council for a three-year term or to fulfill an unexpired term. All members shall be residents and registered voters of the city. 
(d)  To establish a quorum for the meeting, four members must be present, one of whom may be the chairperson. 
(e)  The meetings of the planning commission shall be conducted according to Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, unless otherwise stated prior to the meeting. 
(f)  The planning commission shall hear all matters pertaining to zoning and use of land. 
(g)  The planning commission shall act as an advisory board to the council in all matters pertaining to zoning, present or future, and use of land. 
(Code 1986, § 8-5-3; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 1, 5-18-09)

DIVISION 7. - LICENSE REVIEW BOARD 

Sec. 2-115. - Established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a license review board. 
(b)  The license review board established by this section shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To hear due cause hearings as provided in chapter 6 of this Code. 
(2)  To consider and act upon any matters specifically delegated to the license review board by any other city ordinance or resolution or action of the city council. 
(c)  Applicants or licensee shall be given notice of the date, time and place when the license review board will consider the respective matter. 
(d)  The license review board, other than as expressly provided in chapter 6, shall have no authority or jurisdiction to hear, consider or render decisions of any kind with respect to the suspension, revocation, probation or other disciplinary action against a license or licensee. 
(e)  Any decision or recommendation of the license review board may be appealed to the city council pursuant to section 6-63. Any decision or recommendation of the license review board not appealed to the mayor and council must be approved by the city council or set down for a second due cause hearing before the city council. 
(f)  The decision of the city council on an appeal under this article shall be final unless appeal is made to the superior court of the county. Any aggrieved party may appeal a decision of the city council by filing a petition for writ of certiorari to the superior court within 30 days of the decision of the city council. 
(g)  The license review board shall have no jurisdiction or authority to hear any appeal from or to reverse, modify or set aside any decision of the city council. 
(h)  The license review board members shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council and shall be composed of three members determined as follows: 
(1)  Post 1: Mayor appoints with ratification by majority of city council. 
(2)  Post 2: Mayor appoints with ratification by majority of city council. 
(3)  Post 3: Mayor appoints with ratification by majority of city council. 
(i)  If there is a vacancy in any post on the license review board by virtue of a member resigning from any post or any vacancy by virtue of there being no one filling the office set forth for any post, then the mayor shall appoint a replacement for the vacant post. The replacement shall serve temporarily until the city council ratifies such appointment, and in such case, the replacement for the vacant post shall become permanent. If the council fails to ratify such replacement, then the mayor shall appoint a different replacement until a new member for that post is appointed and ratified as provided herein. 
(j)  Post members I and II shall serve a two-year term. Post member III shall serve for a one-year term. By majority vote, the city council may terminate any term prior to the expiration of such term. Terms of service by any board member shall automatically be renewed for an additional term unless terminated by majority action of the mayor and city council. There shall be no limit on the number of times such terms can be renewed. 
(k)  The license review board shall meet at such times as necessary, to be determined by such board, and shall render decisions in public on the date of the consideration by the board. The decision shall then be memorialized in writing and delivered to the affected parties after such decision is announced in public. 
(l)  The license review board shall select one of its members to serve as chair and one of its members to serve as secretary, to serve at the pleasure of the license review board. Minutes and records of all proceedings shall be kept and maintained in the office of the business license office. 
(m)  Each member of the license review board shall either be a resident of the city or have an ownership interest as principal shareholder, general partner or sole proprietor in at least one business that is located in the city. No employee or elected official of the city shall be appointed to the board. The mayor may appoint and the city council may ratify the appointment of any person who is an alcoholic beverage license holder, provided that only one such license holder, if any, serve on the board. 
(Ord. No. 2002-30, 8-5-02; Ord. No. 2007-36, Exh. A, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 2008-23, § 1, 6-16-08)
