Chapter 82 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Limitation on taxing power of municipalities and counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ VIII; taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 82-1—82-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359.1 the city has contracted with the county tax assessor to prepare the city's tax digest, access and collect city ad valorem taxes and invoke remedies permitted for collection of such taxes. 
State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 82-26. - Levied; rate. 
An annual ad valorem tax upon all real and personal property within the city is hereby levied. The millage rate therefor shall be established each year by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-1) 
Sec. 82-27. - Taxation by city. 
The city shall collect ad valorem taxes by notices of the amount due to all residents and property owners of the city. For purposes of chapter 82 of this Code, the term "finance director" shall mean the finance director and/or his or her designee. 
(1)  Administration. 
a.  Except as otherwise provided, the finance director or his or her designee shall be charged with the duty to administer the imposition, collection and enforcement of all taxes and special assessments levied or imposed by the city in accordance with the administrative procedures hereinafter set forth. Said designee may include, but is not limited to a private vendor to administer the imposition, collection and enforcement of all taxes and special assessments levied or imposed by the city. To the extent this Code section fails to provide a designated procedure, said officer shall act in the manner established, if any, for county tax collectors under applicable state law. 
b.  In determining the fair market value of property within its taxing jurisdiction, the city shall use the fair market value as finally determined for the property for county ad valorem tax purposes. 
c.  Following adoption of its current fiscal year budget, the mayor and council shall, by ordinance, adopt a millage rate upon which property subject to ad valorem tax will be billed. Prior to adoption of said millage rate, the governing body shall publish the notice of proposed ad valorem tax rate as required by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-32, as may be amended from time to time. Millage rates shall be calculated using 40 percent of the assessed fair market value of the property upon which the tax is levied. 
d.  The finance director or his or her designee shall issue a bill to be sent to all taxpayers at the address last shown on the county tax digest by regular U.S. mail, with adequate postage thereon; provided, however, failure by the taxpayer to receive a bill shall not constitute grounds for nonpayment or late payment of the tax. The bill shall state the location or description of the property taxed, 100 percent of the assessed fair market value of the property and its taxable value (40 percent of fair market value), and the amount of tax due thereon. The bill shall also state the due date after which taxes shall be in default. The bill may also contain such additional information as allowed by law or authorized by the mayor and council. 
(2)  Due date; payment; interest on past due taxes. 
a.  All ad valorem taxes shall be due and payable in full within 60 days after notice, unless the due date falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, in which case it shall be postponed until the first day following which is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday. All payments must be United States postmarked no later than the due date. Supplemental ad valorem taxes and special assessments shall be due and payable on the date set forth in the ordinance imposing the tax or assessment. 
b.  All taxes and assessments imposed by the city shall be paid in full in legal tender of the United States; except where specifically authorized by law or ordinance of the mayor and council. 
c.  Taxes and special assessments shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly from the date the tax or assessment is due until the date the tax or assessment is paid. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. For purposes of this section, any period of less than one month shall be considered to be one full month. The finance director or city manager may waive the collection of any interest, in whole or in part, due the city on unpaid taxes or assessments whenever or to the extent that he or she reasonably determines that the delay in payment was attributable to the action or inaction of his or her department. 
(3)  Penalties. 
a.  All penalties imposed herein are part of the tax or assessment and are to be collected as such. The proceedings to collect the original tax, the tax constituted from penalties imposed, and the interest shall all be conducted in the same manner. Any provision of law for criminal prosecution shall not operate to relieve any taxpayer of any tax, penalty, or interest imposed herein. 
b.  In any instance in which any person willfully fails to pay, within 120 days of the date when due, any ad valorem tax owed the city, such person shall pay, in the absence of a specific statutory civil penalty for the failure, a penalty of five percent of the amount of tax due and not paid at the time such penalty is assessed, together with interest as specified by law. After 120 days from the imposition of the initial penalty, an additional penalty of five percent of any tax amount remaining due shall be imposed, together with interest as specified by law. If any tax amount remains due after 120 days from the imposition of such additional penalty, a penalty of five percent shall be imposed, together with interest as specified by law. Should any tax amount remain due 120 days after such date, a penalty of five percent shall be imposed, together with interest as specified by law. The aggregate amount of penalties imposed pursuant to this subsection shall not exceed an amount equal to 20 percent of the principal amount of the tax originally due. 
c.  The finance director or city manager may waive, in whole or in part, the collection of any amount due as a penalty under this Code section to the extent said body finds and determines the default giving rise to the penalty was due to reasonable cause and not due to willful neglect or disregard of this Code section. 
(4)  Executions on delinquent taxes and assessments. 
a.  As soon as the last day for the payment of taxes and assessments has arrived, the finance director or his or her designee shall notify in writing the taxpayer of the fact that the taxes have not been paid and that, unless paid within 30 days, an execution shall be issued. 
b.  The finance director or his or her designee shall issue executions, for the nonpayment of taxes and assessments at any time after 30 days have elapsed since giving notice as provided in subsection (4)a. of this section. The execution shall identify the defendant in fi. fa., (taxpayer), the year(s) for which delinquent taxes are being executed, and the amount thereof. Executions shall be directed to "all and singular sheriffs and constables of the state" as required by O.C.G.A. § 48-3-3. 
c.  The finance director or his or her designee shall cause all executions issued to be recorded on the general execution docket of the county where the property is located, in the case of real property, and, in the case of personal property, in the county of the taxpayer's residence if a resident of the state, otherwise in the county where any real or personal property of the taxpayer may be found. If the taxpayer is not a resident of the state and has no known real or personal property within the state, the execution shall be recorded in the county in which the act or activity giving rise to tax liability took place. 
d.  All executions issued shall continue to bear interest and penalties at the rates established in this section for past due taxes and assessments. 
e.  The finance director shall exercise his or her best efforts to collect the full amount of taxes and assessments due, together with all interest, penalties, and any costs due thereon, from the defendant in fi. fa. In the event he or she is unable to do so, the finance director shall levy the execution on a sufficient amount of the defendant in fi. fa.'s property, whether real or personal, to satisfy the obligations due at a sale to be held and conducted in accordance with this Code section. 
(5)  Levy of executions; sale of property. 
a.  The finance director is hereby designated as the duly authorized officer of the city for tax sales and delegated the duties set forth herein. The finance director shall be subject to being ruled for money in his or her hands arising from the public sale of any property pursuant to process issued by the municipality. After first paying the city the amount due on the process under which the sale was made, the finance director shall pay any surplus to any lawful claimant holding an interest subordinate to the lien for taxes, else to the defendant in fi. fa. 
b.  In all cases of levying on real property, within five days' written notice of the levy must be given personally, or delivered by certified mail, to the defendant in fi. fa. and to any tenants in possession. If the land is unoccupied, a copy of the notice of levy shall also be conspicuously posted on the land. In the case of personal property, the finance director shall enter the same on the execution and plainly describe the property levied on and the amount of the interest of the defendant in fi. fa. therein. 
c.  Whenever any real property is levied upon for taxes or assessments, it shall be the finance director's duty before proceeding to advertise the property for sale to give 20 days' written notice of the levy to the record owner(s) of the property and the holder of each security deed of record. The 20-day period shall begin to run from the time the notice is personally delivered or, when delivered by registered or certified mail with return receipt requested, from the date of mailing. The notice shall contain a description of the land levied upon, the name of the owner of the land, the year or years for which the taxes were assessed, and a statement of the amount of the taxes due, together with accrued costs. The finance director shall keep a copy of the notice on which he shall enter the date the notice was delivered or mailed and how, where, and to whom the notice was delivered. 
d.  When a levy is made upon real or personal property, the property shall be advertised and sold by the finance director in the same manner as provided for executions and judicial sales; provided, however, in addition to such other notice as may be required by law, the defendant in fi. fa. shall be given at least ten days' written notice of such sale by registered or certified mail or statutory overnight delivery as follows: 
1.  In cases of executions issued by a municipal officer for ad valorem taxes, to the property owner's last known address as listed in the records of the municipal officer of the municipality that issued the tax execution; or 
2.  In cases of executions issued by a county officer for ad valorem taxes, the property owner's last known address as listed in the records of the tax commission of the county that issued the tax execution. 
e.  A copy of the notice provided for herein shall also be sent by the same tax officer sending the notice to the property owner to the appropriate tax official of the state, county or municipality which also has issued an execution with respect to such property. In addition, if the United States has a claim or lien on the property subject to being sold and such lien was filed or recorded more than 30 days before the proposed sale, the finance director shall cause written notice of the sale to be given to the secretary of the treasury or his or her delegate not less than 25 days before the sale. Notice may be given either by personal service or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
f.  In all cases of levying on real property, within five days' written notice of the levy must be given personally, or delivered by certified mail, to the defendant in fi. fa. and to any tenants in possession. If the land is unoccupied, a copy of the notice of levy shall also be conspicuously posted on the land. In the case of personal property, the finance director shall enter the same on the execution and plainly describe the property levied on and the amount of the interest of the defendant in fi. fa. therein. 
The finance director shall publish weekly for four weeks in the official legal organ of the county in which the sale will be conducted an advertisement of the date, place, and hours during which the sale will be conducted, together with a full and complete description of the property to be sold, making known the names of the property owner(s) of record and any person who may be in possession of the property. The notice shall state the property is being sold for collection of taxes due to the city and the year(s) for which taxes have been executed. 
g.  Sales of property under execution shall be made by the finance director at the city council chambers on the first Tuesday in each month between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. eastern standard time or eastern daylight savings time, which is applicable, and at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash; provided, however, should the first Tuesday of the month fall on New Year's Day, Independence Day or other city designated holiday, such sales shall take place on the immediately following Wednesday. The purchaser shall look for himself as to the title and soundness of all property sold under tax executions and neither the finance director conducting the sale, nor the city, make any representations or warranty of title, condition, or fitness for a particular purpose, expressed or implied. 
h.  The finance director shall sell the property to the highest bidder for cash and, upon collection of the sales price, make a deed or bill of sale to the purchaser. Any person who becomes the purchaser of any property sold at the sale, who fails or refuses to comply with the terms of sale when requested by the finance director to do so, shall be liable for the amount of the purchase money. It shall be the option of the finance director either to proceed against the purchaser for the full amount of the purchase money or to resell the property and then proceed against the first purchaser for any deficiency. A tax deed for real property, or bill of sale for personal property, made and delivered as evidence of a sale for taxes conducted pursuant to this Code section shall convey the title as effectually as if the sale were made by the person against whom the process was issued. Sales of personal property shall be final; real property sold by virtue of an execution issued for the collection of taxes or for any special assessments is subject to redemption rights of the defendant in fi. fa. or any person having any right, title, or interest in or lien upon such property at the time of levy or sale. Recitals in a deed or bill of sale under power of sale for taxes shall be prima facie evidence of the facts recited in the instrument. The finance director shall put the purchaser in possession of the property so sold; provided, however, the purchaser of real property is not entitled to be placed in possession until after the time for redemption has expired. 
i.  Whenever no bids are forthcoming on property sold for taxes after the property has been offered a reasonable time, the finance director may either re-advertise and sell the property at a later date or abandon the property. The finance director shall make a proper notation on the execution whenever property levied upon and exposed for sale has been abandoned due to lack of bids. 
(6)  Bidding by city at tax sales; disposition of property acquired. 
a.  If, during any sale of property for taxes and after the property has been offered a reasonable time, no one present at the sale bids an amount for the property being sold which is as much as the total of the taxes due (including any priority liens for taxes due the state, county and school and other special tax districts of the state) plus the finance director's cost due on the sale, then the city manager, or his or her designee, may purchase the property for the city. If the city purchases property at a sale, the finance director shall make to the city a deed to the property sold and shall deliver the deed to the city manager. The finance director shall put the city in possession of the property so sold. 
b.  Property acquired by the city pursuant to a sale for taxes or assessments may be divested or alienated by the city only by public sale of the property to the highest bidder, however, when the city has not parted with title to the property, the city may quitclaim the property to the owner at the time of the tax sale, or to the owner's administrators, executors, heirs, or assigns, upon full payment of the redemption price provided herein. 
c.  The right of redemption in real property purchased by the city at a tax sale shall be foreclosed in the manner set forth herein. 
(7)  Accounting by finance director; final return or settlement. 
a.  The finance director shall make a prompt accounting for all executions placed in his or her hands for collection or levy and sale. He or she shall pay all amounts due to the city for taxes and assessments, interest, penalties, and costs, and shall file a final written return or settlement showing the amounts so paid, together with disposition of any excess proceeds derived from the sale. If there is any excess after paying taxes, costs, and all expenses of a sale, the finance director shall retain the balance of the funds in his hands until he or she is ordered by the court first acquiring jurisdiction under proper proceedings to pay out the funds, as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-4-5, as may be amended from time to time. 
b.  It shall be the duty of the finance director to cause cancellation of executions on the general execution docket of the county upon their final payment or collection. 
(8)  Garnishments by city; reduction of executions to judgment. 
a.  Whenever the finance director can find no property belonging to a defendant in fi. fa. on which to levy any tax execution in his or her hands, he or she shall make an entry to that effect on the execution. The finance director, in the name of the city, may then petition any court of competent jurisdiction to issue a summons of garnishment against any person whom he or she believes to be indebted to the defendant in fi. fa. or who has property, money, or effects in his hands belonging to the defendant in fi. fa. The finance director shall enter upon the execution the names of the persons garnished and the court and file number of the action where the garnishment is filed. All subsequent proceedings shall be the same as provided by law in other cases where judgments have been obtained or execution issued. 
b.  When an execution for taxes remains unsatisfied and an entry of "nulla bona" has been duly entered by the finance director on the execution within the immediately preceding 30-day period and the finance director has reason to believe the defendant in fi. fa. may have or may come into ownership of assets outside the state, the finance director, in the name of the city, may petition the superior court of the county in this state in which the defendant in fi. fa. maintains a known residence, place of business, or agent to receive service, to reduce the execution to judgment. If the defendant in fi. fa. does not maintain a known residence in this state, the action may be brought in the county where the tax obligation arose. This and all subsequent proceedings shall be brought in accordance with O.C.G.A. ch. 3 of tit. 48, as may be amended from time to time. 
(9)  Redemption rights of defendant in fi. fa.; vesting of title in grantee. 
a.  Whenever real property is sold for taxes or any special assessment, the defendant in fi. fa. or any person having any right, title, or interest in or lien upon such property may redeem the property from the sale by the payment of the redemption price or the amount required for redemption as fixed by O.C.G.A. § 48-4-42, as may be amended from time to time, at any time within 12 months from the date of sale, and at any time after the sale until the right to redeem is foreclosed by the giving of the notice provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-4-45, as may be amended from time to time, which code sections by reference are incorporated herein as a part of the code. 
b.  Where notice of foreclosure of the right to redeem real property sold at a tax sale has not been given as required in subsection (1) of this section, title shall ripen by prescription after a period of four years from the date of recording of the deed in the county where the property is situated, provided the defendant in fi. fa. was not laboring under any legal disability at the time of sale. Unless the tax deed indicates a lesser interest was levied upon and sold, a fee simple title to the property shall vest absolutely in the grantee in the deed or in the grantee's heirs or assigns. In the event the defendant in fi. fa. is laboring under any legal disability, the prescriptive term shall begin from the time the disabilities are removed or abated. 
(10)  Costs. 
a.  For issuing executions, the city shall receive an amount equal to any filing fees charged by the clerk of superior court for recording and cancellations of the tax fi. fa. 
b.  Once a levy is made or posted on the property of a defendant in fi. fa., the finance director shall collect all costs, including but not limited to all taxes, interest, penalties, postage, advertising fees, posting fees, attorney fees, title search fees, tax deed preparation, collection fees and all other costs heretofore accrued. 
c.  The costs provided in this section shall be cumulative and in addition to any statutory premiums allowed as a part of the redemption price. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-2; Ord. No. 2006-24, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2007-19, 7-2-07; Ord. No. 2016-23, 9-19-16; Ord. No. 2017-04, 3-6-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-04, adopted March 6, 2017, amended the title of § 82-27 to read as herein set out. Former § 82-27 was titled, "Taxation by city; certain past due collections by county authorized." 
Sec. 82-28. - Tax liens—Authority to place. 
Either the finance director or his or her designee may be authorized by the mayor and council to place a tax lien upon the general execution docket of the superior court of the county against any person who fails to pay city taxes prior to the delinquency date; the due date being determined by the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-3; Ord. No. 2006-24, 9-18-06) 
Sec. 82-29. - Same—Satisfying; interest on past due taxes. 
Either the finance director or his or her designee is authorized to satisfy all tax liens placed upon the general execution docket when and if the delinquent taxes are paid, along with a penalty and interest calculated as set forth in section 82-27 by any party of interest. The finance director or his or her designee shall obtain permission from the mayor and council before foreclosure is filed on any property upon which a tax lien has been placed. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-4; Ord. No. 2006-24, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2016-23, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 82-30. - Homestead tax exemption. 
Any resident over 65 years of age is exempt from the city ad valorem property tax for the property on which they reside. 
(Ord. No. 1959-120, 5-15-00) 
Sec. 82-31. - Assessed value homestead exemption. 
A homestead exemption from certain city ad valorem taxes for municipal purposes in an amount equal to the amount by which the current year assessed value of a homestead exceeds the base year assessed value of such homestead. 
(H.B. No. 1712, §§ 1—4, appd. by electors 11-7-00) 
Secs. 82-32—82-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE EXCISE TAXES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to impose excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-130; levy of tax on sale of distilled spirits by the package authorized, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80; imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80. 

Sec. 82-51. - Levied. 
In addition to all other taxes or license fees imposed upon dealers engaged in the city in the business of selling alcoholic beverages, there is imposed and levied upon all dealers described in this article within the city an excise tax, to be computed and collected as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-51) 
Sec. 82-52. - Distilled spirits and wine. 
(a)  The tax levied under this article on distilled spirits and wine shall be computed on the basis of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a gallon (liter) for all distilled spirits and/or wine sold or delivered within the city. The excise tax shall be imposed on the retail dealer and collected by wholesalers provided however, that such taxes shall be imposed upon and shall be paid by the licensed manufacturer of distilled spirits and wine served or sold by the manufacturer directly to the public as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The tax imposed in this section shall be computable and payable monthly. Each wholesale dealer, manufacturer or distributor selling, shipping or delivering distilled spirits or wine to any retail dealer in the city, whether delivered to the retail dealer's place of business in the city, elsewhere for resale in the city or directly to the public, as a condition to the privilege of carrying on that business in the city shall: 
(1)  Keep true and correct records of all sales, shipments, or deliveries of each class of distilled spirits and/or wine to each retail dealer in the city, as well as sales directly to the public, such records to be preserved for a period of two years and to be made available on request for the inspection of any duly authorized representative of the city. 
(2)  Collect from each such retail dealer in the city, as well as sales directly to the public, at the time of delivery of the distilled spirits and/or wine the amount of tax due under the terms of this section and hold such tax in trust for the city until such amount is remitted to the city as provided under subsection (b)(3) of this section. 
(3)  On or before the 20th day of each calendar month make a verified and comprehensive report to the city which shall correctly show all sales and deliveries of each class of distilled spirits and/or wine to or for retail dealers in the city, as well as sales directly to the public, for the month immediately preceding such report. Such report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer, the quantities of each class of distilled spirits and/or wine delivered to each retail dealer, the amount collected under the terms of this section, and such other information as may be called for by the city. Such report shall show the quantities of each class of distilled spirits and/or wine sold directly to the public, the amount collected under the terms of this section, and such other information as may be called for by the city. Such report shall be accompanied by a remittance to the city for all taxes collected or due as shown on such report. There is assessed a ten percent late charge on the gross tax due for failure to remit the excise tax by the 20th of the month. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-52; Ord. No. 2017-10, § 9, 8-21-17) 
State Law reference— Excise tax on package sales of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80; on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60. 
Sec. 82-53. - Malt beverages. 
(a)  The tax levied on malt beverages is imposed on wholesale dealers; provided however, that such taxes shall be imposed upon and shall be paid by the licensed brewer for malt beverages served or sold by the brewer directly to the public, and shall be computed on the following basis: 
(1)  Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons; 
(2)  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
(b)  The method of reporting and payment of malt beverage taxes shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-53; Ord. No. 2017-10, § 10, 8-21-17) 
State Law reference— Malt beverage excise taxes, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80 et seq. 
Sec. 82-54. - Invoices. 
Upon each delivery by a licensed wholesaler to a licensed retailer, an invoice in triplicate shall be prepared, showing the classes, quantities and brands of alcoholic beverages delivered together with the price thereof and the tax collected thereon. The original copy of such invoice shall be delivered by the wholesaler to the retailer simultaneously with each such delivery. The wholesaler shall retain the second copy of such invoice and shall keep it for a period of 24 months. The wholesaler shall keep such invoices for 24 months after the date of such invoices, and during that period such invoices shall be made available for inspection by authorized representatives of the city. If requested by an authorized representative of the city, a copy of such invoices shall be attached to any reports requested or required by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-54) 
Sec. 82-55. - Noncompliance by wholesale dealer or distributor. 
If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the reports provided for in this article, the city shall notify the party in writing, and if the reports are not made and the taxes remitted within five days from the date of notice, the city may withdraw from the wholesale dealer or distributor the privilege of doing business in the city by revoking his permit or license. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-55) 
Sec. 82-56. - Sale of nontax-paid beverage. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any person to sell at retail within the limits of the city any alcoholic beverages on which the taxes provided for in this article have not been paid. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-56) 
Sec. 82-57. - Delivery of nontax-paid beverage. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any wholesale dealer or distributor, or other person, to deliver any distilled spirits and/or wine to any retail dealer in the city without collecting the taxes provided for in this article at the time of delivery. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-57) 
Sec. 82-58. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article or who shall assist any retail dealer in alcoholic beverages in the city to evade or avoid the payment of the taxes provided for in this article shall be guilty of a violation of this Code and, upon conviction, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-11, and such person so convicted shall also be subject to having his license revoked. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-58) 
Sec. 82-59. - Sales of spirituous liquors by the drink. 
(a)  Imposition and rate of tax. There is hereby imposed and levied upon every sale of spirituous liquor purchased by the drink in the city a tax in the amount of three percent of the purchase price of such drink. 
(b)  Purchaser's receipt; credit or deferred payment. Every licensee for the sale of spirituous liquor by the drink for operation of a place of business in the city shall, at the time of collecting for food and drinks served, give to the purchaser a receipt on which the price of alcoholic beverage served shall be itemized separately and where the charges for food and drink are satisfied by credit or deferred in a like manner. The licensee shall itemize the charges therefore separately on the charge billing at the time and to the extent that such credits are incurred. 
(c)  Person liable for collection of tax. Every licensee or his agent is hereby authorized and directed to collect the tax imposed in this division from purchasers of spirituous liquors by the drink sold within his licensed premises. Such licensee or his agent shall furnish such information as may be requested by the city to facilitate the collection of this tax. 
(d)  Determinations, returns and payments. 
(1)  Due date of taxes. All taxes collected by any licensee or agent under this section shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the twentieth day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period. 
(2)  Return; time of filing. On or before the twentieth day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the business license clerk's office in such form as the business license clerk may prescribe for every licensee or agent liable for the payment of tax under this section. 
(3)  Contents of return. All returns required by this section shall show the gross receipts from the sale of spirituous liquors by the drink, the amount of tax collected or due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the city. 
(4)  Delivery of return and remittance. The person required to file the return under this section shall deliver the return, together with the remittance of the net amount of tax due, to the Business License Clerk's Office, 2529 J.O. Stephenson Avenue, Kennesaw, GA 30144. 
(5)  Collection fee. Operators collecting the tax imposed under this section shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction for submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from the state tax under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. I (O.C.G.A. §48-8-1 et seq.), as amended. 
(e)  Deficiency determinations. 
(1)  Recomputation of tax; authority to make basis of recomputation. If the business license clerk is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax to be paid to the city by any licensee, the clerk may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. Deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(2)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the deficiency determination under this section, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall be assessed for each month or fraction thereof from the close of the monthly period in which the amount of any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(3)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a deficiency determination under this section, the business license clerk may offset overpayments, for a period or periods, against underpayments for another period or periods, against penalties and against the interest on underpayments. The interest on overpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (f). 
(4)  Penalty; negligence or disregard of rules or regulations. If any part of the deficiency determination under this section has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty in the amount of ten percent of the amount of such taxes shall be added to the amount of the deficiency. 
(5)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination under this section is made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provisions of this division or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the deficiency shall be added thereto. 
(6)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of fraud, intent to evade this division or authorized rules or regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the twentieth day of every month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(7)  Collection of unpaid fees, taxes or penalties. If any person shall fail or neglect to pay any license fee, tax or penalty as required by this division, such fee, tax or penalty is subject to collection in the manner as provided for the collection of taxes, regardless of the provisions of this section for penalties. 
(f)  Determination if no return made. 
(1)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return as required by this division, the business license clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the total sales in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is in or may come into the possession of the city. Upon the basis of this estimate, the business license clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or more than one period. 
(2)  Manner of computation; offsets; interest. In making a determination of tax due under this section, the business license clerk may offset overpayments for a period or penalties against the interest on the underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed at one percent per month. 
(3)  Interest on amount due. The amount of the determination of tax due under this division, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly from the date the tax or assessment is due until the date the tax or assessment is paid. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. For purposes of this section, any period of less than one month shall be considered to be one full month. The finance director or city manager may waive the collection of any interest, in whole or in part, due the city on unpaid taxes or assessments whenever or to the extent that he or she reasonably determines that the delay in payment was attributable to the action or inaction of his or her department. 
(4)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If the failure to file a return for taxes due under this section is due to fraud or an intent to evade this section or rules and regulations, penalties shall be assessed at 25 percent of the deficiency, which penalty shall be added thereto. 
(5)  Written notice, manner of service. Promptly after making the determination of taxes due under this section, the business license clerk shall give to the person written notice to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. 
(g)  Collection of tax. 
(1)  Notice of delinquency to persons holding credits or property of delinquent; duty of persons so notified. If any person is delinquent in the payment of the amount required to be paid by him under this section or if a determination has been made against him which remains unpaid, the business license clerk may, not later than three years after the payment became delinquent, give notice thereof by registered mail to all persons in the city having in their possession or under their control any credits or other personal property belonging to the delinquent, or owning any debts to the delinquent. After receiving the notice, the persons so notified shall neither transfer nor make any other disposition of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession owned by them or under their control at the time they receive the notice until the business license clerk consents to a transfer or disposition or until 20 days elapse after the receipt of the notice. All persons so notified shall within five days after receipt of the notice advise the clerk of all these credits, other personal property or debts in their possession, under their control or owing by them. 
(2)  Action for tax; time for. Any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required under this section became delinquent or any amount of tax was required to be collected, the business license clerk may bring an action in the courts of this state, or any other state, or of the United States, in the name of the county to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(3)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount under this section sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces receipts from the business license clerk showing that the city has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. The purchaser of the business may not operate the business until the requirements of this subscription are met. 
(4)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required by this section, he becomes personally liable for a portion of the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him valued in money. Within 30 days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the business license clerk shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the city of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. 
(h)  Administration of this division. 
(1)  Authority of business license clerk. The business license clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this section. 
(2)  Rules and regulations. The business license clerk shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this division or other laws of the city, of the county and the state, or the constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this section and the collection of taxes under this section. 
(3)  Records required of licensee, form. Every licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink in this city shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the business license clerk may require. 
(4)  Examination of records; audit. The business license clerk or any person authorized in writing by the city manager may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee liable for the tax imposed by this section, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the licensee, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(5)  Authority to require reports; contents. In the administration of the provisions of this section, the business license clerk may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's or class of person's possession or custody information relating to sales of alcoholic beverages which are subject to any tax. The reports shall be filed with the business license clerk when required by the city manager and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the date or dates of sales, and such other information as the business license clerk may require. 
(6)  Disclosure of business of licensee; limitations on rule. The business license clerk or any person having an administrative duty under this section shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operation or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return or permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this chapter, except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators and assignees, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax required to be collected, interest and penalties. 
(i)  Revocation of license. The continuous failure to pay the tax prescribed by this section shall render the dealer or person liable therefor subject to revocation of their alcoholic beverage license in accordance with the procedures set out in section 6-61. 
(Ord. No. 1999-02, 1-4-99; Ord. No. 2016-23, 9-19-16) 
State Law reference— Authority to impose excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by drink, O.C.G.A. 3-4-130. 
Secs. 82-60—82-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOTEL-MOTEL EXCISE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Tourist courts, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-1 et seq.; local excise taxes on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq. 

Sec. 82-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hotel means and includes the terms motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for rent value. 
Permanent resident means any person occupying a guestroom in a hotel as defined in this section for a period of more than ten consecutive days. 
Trailer camp means a campground or park for the overnight or temporary parking of trailers and other recreational vehicles for which charges are made as rental for the space occupied. No trailer or recreational vehicle may occupy a trailer camp for more than 14 days in any 60-day period. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-31; Ord. No. 1999-06, 6-7-99) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-82. - Hotel-motel excise tax imposed. 
(a)  The hotel-motel excise tax to be collected under this article is hereby levied pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(5.1) and shall be imposed at a rate of eight percent for all lodging charges actually collected for any room, lodging, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. 
(b)  The hotel-motel excise tax imposed by this section shall also be paid for the occupancy of a rental space in a trailer camp. 
(c)  The proceeds of this tax shall be used in accordance with the dictates of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(5.1). 
(d)  The quarterly periods referenced hereinafter in this article for the filing of returns and the payment of the tax levied herein shall be in any calendar year as follows: 
January 1 — March 31; 
April 1 — June 30; 
July 1 — September 30; 
October 1 — December 31. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-32; Ord. No. 2005-25, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 82-83. - Collection by operator. 
Every operator or owner maintaining a business regulated by this article in the city shall collect the tax of eight percent on the amount of rent from the occupants. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-33) 
Sec. 82-84. - Exemptions. 
No tax shall be imposed under this article upon the following: 
(1)  Any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention, or other buildings in which human beings are housed or detained under legal restraint; 
(2)  Any charges made for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations provided to any persons who certify that they are staying in such room, lodging, or accommodations as a result of the destruction of their home or residence by fire or other casualty; 
(3)  Any fees and charges made for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations which are charged for occupancy after the first ten days of continuous occupancy of a permanent resident; however, any fees and charges made for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations which are charged for the first ten days of continuous occupancy of a permanent resident shall be subject to the tax herein; 
(4)  Any charges made for the use of meeting rooms and other such facilities; 
(5)  To any room, lodgings, or accommodations provided without charge; 
(6)  Any charges for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished for a period of one or more days for use by state or local governmental officials or employees when traveling on official business. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-34; Ord. No. 1999-06, 6-7-99) 
Sec. 82-85. - Registration of operator; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. 
Every person engaging in or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in this city shall immediately register with the business license clerk on a form provided by the clerk. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place or places of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the clerk may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The business license clerk shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-35; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 82-86. - Determination of tax; returns and payments. 
(a)  Due date. All amounts of taxes levied under this article shall be due and payable to the business license clerk on or before April 30, July 31, October 31 and January 31 next succeeding each respective quarterly period set forth in section 82-82. 
(b)  Return; time of filing; contents. On or before the last day of the month following each quarterly period, a return for the preceding quarterly period shall be filed with the business license clerk showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax due under this article, and such other information as may be required by the business license clerk. 
(c)  Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax due under this article shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under the Georgia Retailers' and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act, approved February 20, 1951 (1951 Ga. Laws, page 360), as amended. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-36; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 82-87. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax. If the business license clerk is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city under this article by any person, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the determination of tax by the business license clerk under subsection (a) of this section shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly from the date the tax or assessment is due until the date the tax or assessment is paid. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall be assessed for each month or fraction thereof from the close of the monthly period in which the amount of any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(c)  Notice of determination; service of. The business license clerk or his or her designated representative shall give to the operator written notice of his or her determination of tax under this section. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his or her address as it appears in the records of the business license clerk. Service by mail of any notice required by this article is complete at the time of deposit in the United States Postal Service. 
(d)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination under this section shall be mailed within three years after the last day of the calendar month following the quarterly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-37; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 82-88. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any person fails to make a return as required by this article, the business license clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the business license clerk. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in section 82-87(c). 
(b)  Interest on amount due. The amount of the determination of tax due under this article shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly from the date the tax or assessment is due until the date the tax or assessment is paid. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall be assessed for each month or fraction thereof from the close of the monthly period in which the amount of any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-38; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 82-89. - Administration of article. 
(a)  Authority of business license clerk. The business license clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(b)  Records required from operators. Every operator renting guestrooms in this city to a person shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the business license clerk may require. 
(c)  Examination of records; audits. The business license clerk or any person authorized in writing by the clerk may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator liable for the tax imposed by this article, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(d)  Authority to require reports, contents. For purposes of the administration of the provisions of this article, the business license clerk may require the filing of reports by any person having possession or custody of information relating to rentals of guestrooms subject to the tax imposed by this article. The reports shall be filed with the business license clerk when required by the clerk, and shall set forth such information as required by the clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-39; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 82-90. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provisions of the article is committed, continued, or permitted by such person, and shall be punished accordingly. Any operator or any person who fails to register as required in this article, or to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the business license clerk, or who renders a false or fraudulent return shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as aforesaid. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-40; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 82-91. - Collection of tax. 
(a)  Action for delinquent taxes. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected by this article becomes due and payable and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the business license clerk may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount of tax under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the business license clerk showing that he has paid such tax or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required in this section, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. 
(d)  Refund or credit for overpayments. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalties or interest due under this article has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city, it may be refunded by the business license clerk. If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid the amount of tax due, he will have three years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific grounds upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the business license clerk, the excess amount paid to the city may be refunded or credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid, or his administrators or executors. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-41; Ord. No. 2017-09, 8-21-17) 
Secs. 82-92—82-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TELEPHONE COMPANY TAX[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Power to grant franchise or make contract with public utilities, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(7); limitation on expanding the power of municipal regulation over any business activity regulated by the Public Service Commission, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(5). 

Sec. 82-111. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Recurring local service revenue means: 
(1)  Monthly charges for local exchange service, including: 
a.  Charges for additional listings and joint users; 
b.  The guarantee portion of the charge for semipublic pay station services; 
c.  Charges for local message rate service, including mobile service local messages; and 
d.  Subscriber station revenues from teletypewriter exchange service; 
(2)  Charges for Morse transmission, signaling, data transmission, remote metering and supervisory control, where both terminal points are within the city; 
(3)  All charges for local private line services, except audio and video program transmission services, where both terminals of the private line are within the city. 
Nothing in this definition shall preclude the charging of a separate franchise fee for the transmission of audio or video programs to customers by CATV companies. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-24(b), (c)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-112. - Imposed; due date. 
Each telephone company operating in the city shall pay an occupational license tax in the amount of three percent of the recurring local service revenues received by such company from subscribers located within the city. Such occupational license tax shall be paid in quarterly installments, each of which shall be due on or before the last day of the second month following the end of each calendar quarter and shall be based on recurring local service revenues billed during such calendar quarter. 
(Code 1986, § 3-2-24(a)) 
Secs. 82-113—82-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - REDEVELOPMENT POWERS 

Sec. 82-200. - Exercise of redevelopment powers. 
The city is hereby authorized to exercise redevelopment powers under the "Redevelopment Powers Laws" as it may be amended from time to time. 
(H.B. No. 1753, §§ 1—4, appd. by electors 11-7-00) 
ARTICLE VII. - RENTAL MOTOR VEHICLES EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 82-220. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Month or monthly period shall mean the calendar months of any year. 
Rental charge means the total value received by a rental motor vehicle concern from the rental or lease for 31 or fewer consecutive days of a rental motor vehicle, including the total cash and non-monetary consideration for the rental or lease including, but not limited to, charges based on time or mileage and charges for insurance coverage of collision damage waiver but excluding all charges for motor fuel taxes or sales taxes. 
Rental motor vehicle means a motor vehicle designed to carry ten or fewer passengers and used primarily for the transportation of persons that is rented or leased without a driver regardless of whether such vehicle is licensed in the state. 
Rental motor vehicle concern means a person or legal entity, which owns or leases five or more rental motor vehicles and which regularly, rents or leases such vehicles to the public for value. 
Tax, excise tax or taxes shall mean the tax imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-221. - Authority; rules and regulations; records required. 
(a)  Authority. The chief financial officer shall administer and enforce this chapter for the levy and collection of tax. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The chief financial officer shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter or other laws of the city and the state or the constitution of the state or the United States for the administration and enforcement of this chapter and the collection of the tax under this chapter. 
(c)  Records required. Every rental motor vehicles concern subject to this chapter shall keep records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the chief financial officer may require. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-222. - Assessment, levy, and collection. 
(a)  Within the corporate limits of the city, there is assessed and levied an excise tax upon each rental charge collected by any rental motor vehicle concern when such charge constitutes a taxable event for the purposes of the sales and use tax as provided for under article I, chapter 1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. The tax levied pursuant to this chapter shall be imposed only at the time when and the place where a customer pays sales tax with respect to the rental charge. The customer who pays a rental charge that is subject to the tax levy as provided in this chapter shall be liable for the tax. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern. The tax shall be a debt of the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery for other debts. 
(b)  The rental motor vehicle concern collecting the tax shall remit the tax to the chief financial officer of the city and the tax thus remitted shall be a credit against the tax imposed by this chapter on the rental motor vehicle concern. Every rental motor vehicle concern subject to the tax levied by this chapter shall be liable for the tax at the rate of three percent upon the rental charges actually collected or the amount of taxes collected from the customers, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-223. - Authorized capital outlay projects. 
The following projects and purposes for which the proceeds of the tax levied by this chapter are to be expended are specified as follows: 
(1)  Promoting tourism for the Southern Museum of Civil War and Locomotive History. 
(2)  Capital outlay project, Southern Museum of Civil War and Locomotive History at 2829 Cherokee Street, Kennesaw, Georgia. (The payment or prepayment of outstanding bonded indebtedness used to finance, refinance or related to the above; or any combination of the above.) 
(3)  Maintenance and operation expenses or security and public safety expenses associated with subsection (2) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-224. - No tax imposed. 
No tax shall be imposed pursuant to this chapter on the rental charge associated with the rental or lease of a rental motor vehicle if either: 
(1)  The customer picks up the rental motor vehicle outside the State of Georgia and returns it within the State of Georgia; or 
(2)  The customer picks up the rental motor vehicle in the State of Georgia and returns it outside the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-225. - Collection allowance. 
Each rental motor vehicle concern collecting the tax imposed by this chapter shall be allowed to retain three percent of the tax due and collected and may retain that amount in the form of a deduction for expenses incurred in submitting, reporting and paying the amount of taxes due, if the amounts due are not delinquent at the time of payment. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-226. - Payment; interest; late charges. 
(a)  On or before the 20th day of each month following the month of March 2005 the rental motor vehicle concern liable for the tax provided for herein shall transmit to the chief financial officer for the city, a statement showing the gross rental charges and gross taxes collected by authority of this chapter for each preceding calendar month. Along with said statement the rental motor vehicle concern shall submit to the chief financial officer the net taxes due for that particular month. 
(b)  Failure to remit taxes by the date shall subject the rental motor vehicle concern to a penalty of five percent of the tax then due and in addition to such penalty, interest thereon on the unpaid principal amount due, computed at the rate of 1½ percent per month. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-227. - Records open for inspection. 
In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and to collect all the tax imposed, all rental motor vehicle concerns are required to keep a record of all rental charges for rental motor vehicles and taxes collected which are related thereto. Said records shall be open for inspection and copying by and duly authorized agent of the city during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-228. - Excise tax return and review. 
(a)  If the chief financial officer is not satisfied with the return of returns of the excise tax provided for herein, or the amount of tax required to be paid to the city by any rental motor vehicle concern, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly period. 
(b)  The amount of the determination made by the chief financial officer shall bear interest at the rate of 1½ percent per month or fraction thereof from the due date of the taxes found to be due by him. 
(c)  The chief financial officer or his designated representative shall give to the rental motor vehicle concern a written notice of any such determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail and if by mail the service shall be addressed to the operator or the owner of the rental motor vehicle concern at the address as the same appears in the records of the chief financial officer as provided to him by each rental motor vehicle concern. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by an addressee or agent of the addressee. 
(d)  Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period in which the amount proposed to be determined or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall expire last. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-229. - Failure to make a return. 
(a)  If any rental motor vehicle concern fails to make a return, the chief financial officer shall make an estimate of the excise tax due. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the rental motor vehicle concern has failed to make the return and shall be based upon such information, which is or may come into the possession of the chief financial officer. Written motion shall be given in the manner as prescribed above in section 82-228(c). 
(b)  The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 1½ percent per month or fraction thereof from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount of any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-330. - Audit authority. 
Duly authorized employees of the city upon exhibition of identification and during regular business hours may examine and copy the books, papers, records, financial reports equipment and other facilities if necessary of any rental motor vehicle concern in order to verify the accuracy of any rental motor vehicle concern, to ascertain or determine the amount of tax required to be paid. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-331. - Withholding tax on sale of business. 
(a)  If any rental motor vehicle concern liable for any amount under this chapter transfers or sells its business or quits the business, its successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient amounts from the purchase price to cover the amount required to be paid pursuant to this chapter until the former owner or operator of the rental motor vehicle concern produces a receipt from the chief financial officer or his designee showing that the indebtedness has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(b)  If the purchaser of a business or rental motor vehicle concern fails to withhold from the purchase price as required herein, such purchaser shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount of the outstanding tax required to be withheld by him to the extent of such purchase price. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Sec. 82-332. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  In addition to the interest charges and delinquent penalties specified in this chapter, any person violating any provision of this chapter, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by the Municipal Court for the City of Kennesaw in accordance with the limits established by the City Charter for the City of Kennesaw. Such persons shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which any violation of this chapter is committed, continued, or permitted by that person and shall be punished accordingly. 
(b)  The tax levied by this chapter shall be effective on the first day of March 2005 and shall continue until its permissible existence shall expire as provided by law, or until otherwise terminated by the Georgia General Assembly or the Kennesaw City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, 2-22-05) 
Chapter 86 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Courts, ch. 38; law enforcement, ch. 58; offenses, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); preventing or disrupting lawful procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34; deposit of driver's license for violations of laws pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11; authority to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on the highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(3); prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq.; traffic offenses triable on complaint without indictment except in superior courts, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-3; alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183; Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; stopping, standing and parking,O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; Handicapped Parking Law, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-220 et seq.; bicycles and play vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-290 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-76; operation of motorcycles and motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7; authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga.
